critical_instructions.item: Analyze ONLY the final image provided for analysis. NEVER analyze any of the example images provided earlier.
Absence of educational transcripts is a valid and expected outcome. Do not force identification.
When in doubt, do NOT classify a document as a transcript. Accuracy is more important than comprehensiveness.
NEVER classify report cards, grade sheets, or course schedules as transcripts.
Transcripts must contain cumulative academic records spanning multiple courses or terms.

transcript_definition.item: A transcript is an official or unofficial document from an educational institution documenting cumulative academic history.
Must include: courses taken, grades earned, credits awarded, and typically cumulative metrics (GPA).
Spans multiple terms, semesters, or academic years - not just a single grading period.
Issued by the institution's registrar or records office.
May include degree conferral information, honors, and authentication features.

not_transcripts.item: Single-term report cards (only show one grading period).
Individual course grade sheets (only show one course).
Diplomas or certificates alone (credential without course history).
Course catalogs (describe available courses, not student records).
Class schedules (show enrolled courses, not completed grades).
Enrollment verification letters (confirm attendance, not grades).
Degree audit worksheets (planning documents, not official records).
Academic planning documents (future courses, not completed work).

level.name: K-12
level.characteristics: Elementary, middle, or high school records.
level.typical_format: Often organized by grade level or academic year.
level.grading: Letter grades (A-F), percentages, or standards-based marks.

level.name: High School
level.typical_format: Organized by year or semester, shows credits toward graduation.
level.grading: Letter grades, GPA on 4.0 scale, class rank common.

level.name: Undergraduate
level.characteristics: College or university bachelor's degree programs.
level.typical_format: Organized by semester/quarter, credit hours, major/minor.
level.grading: Letter grades, 4.0 GPA scale, credit hours.

level.name: Graduate
level.typical_format: Similar to undergraduate, may include thesis/dissertation.
level.grading: Often requires B or higher, may use different GPA thresholds.

level.name: Professional
level.characteristics: Law, medical, dental, or other professional schools.
level.typical_format: May use pass/fail, honors/pass/fail, or letter grades.
level.grading: Varies by program; class rank often emphasized.

level.name: Vocational/Technical
level.characteristics: Trade schools, technical colleges, certification programs.
level.typical_format: May focus on competencies, clock hours, or credit hours.

system.name: Letter Grades (US)
system.scale: A, B, C, D, F (with +/- modifiers)

system.name: Percentage
system.conversion: Often shown with letter grade equivalent.

system.name: International
system.note: Varies widely: 1-10 scales, 1-20 scales, first/second/third class honors, etc.
system.action: Extract as shown; do not convert unless conversion table provided.

authentication_features.feature: Handwritten or printed signature of registrar.
Security watermark in paper or background.

pass_1_identification.step: Look for institutional headers, logos, or school names.
Identify student information sections (name, ID, dates).
Find structured course listings organized by term.
Locate grade columns and credit hour information.
Check for cumulative GPA or performance summaries.

pass_2_verification.step: Confirm document shows CUMULATIVE records (multiple terms/courses).
Verify it's from an educational institution, not a testing service.
Ensure it's a transcript, not a report card or schedule.
Check that grades and credits are present, not just course listings.

common_mistakes_to_avoid.mistake: Classifying a single-semester report card as a transcript.
Extracting a course schedule (no grades) as a transcript.
Confusing a diploma with a transcript.
Inventing course names or grades not visible on the document.
Converting grades between systems without explicit conversion table.
Assuming missing information - only extract what's visible.

decision_process.step: Scan for institutional identification and student information.
Look for structured academic records with courses, grades, and credits.
Verify records span multiple terms or courses (cumulative history).
Confirm this is a transcript, not a report card, schedule, or diploma.
Extract all visible information without inferring missing data.
Note official vs. unofficial status and authentication features.
If criteria not met, respond with not_found format.
